The method of note identification proceeds as such: a teacher plays a note on the piano (out of seven) and the student has to identify the right one.  / These are the only information provided. First of all, we should determine when a student is considered as having a good ear for music. Indeed, we can suppose that the teacher plays subsequently 10 different notes. We can then, for the purpose of the research, suggest that if the student rightly recognizes 7 out of 10 notes, he has a good ear for music. If he fails identifying 7 out of 10 notes (so only identify rightly from 0-6 notes), then he does not have a good ear for music.  / After determining the categories and so dividing the students within two distinctive groups, a test can be conducted on a couple of students. Let's say 10% of a musical/academic school. The randomly chosen students would have to do the test, two times, in order to be sure that there are not other factors that could have influenced the student performance. After analyzing both results, the students will be either categorized as having a good ear for music or not.

I would first identify a group of students who are said to have a "good ear for music" and run through the note identification test with each of them separately. I would make sure that each student was given an identical test, with the same number of notes played and in the same order for each student. After running the trials with each of the students with good ears I would turn the data into an average of the number of correct responses obtain by those with good ears and use this number as a baseline criteria for testing whether or not a student has a good ear for music. I would also calculate the standard deviation between the number of correct responses. I would then run the same test on the students who don't know whether they do or don't have a good ear for music and compare their number or correct responses to the baseline number obtained from the previous tests on the students with good ears for music. If their number of responses was equal to or above this number, or within the standard deviation then it would be determined that they have a good ear for music.

If, for example, Carla could identify the A, B, C, D, and E, for example, she would have successfully identified 5/7 (or about .71) of the notes played. 1.  I could always have Carla listen to notes randomly played by the teacher, or I could simulate the scenario (which may be faster than having Carla listen).  I choose to simulate Carla's note-identification test. /  / 2.  As there are 7 possible notes that Carla could identify, I will be running this simulation for each individual note.  I will only be using 1 note in each simulation I will only use 1 note per simulation as there is only 1 correct note; I will also only use 1 note per simulation so I do not confuse data, such as thinking a simulation counted for note A when it really counted for note F.  /      I will be using a random number table for my simulations, though I will ignore the numbers 0, 8, and 9, because there are only 7 possible notes that can be identified.  I will then assign a specific number to each note:  A=1, B=2, C=3, D=4, E=5, F=6, G=7. /  / 3.  I will conduct 20 trials for note A, counting how many notes are played before the number 1 appears in the table.  I will record how many notes Clara got wrong before she correctly identified A for each of the 20 trials. /      Every note will go through 20 trials, and I will record how many notes Clara got wrong before correctly identifying the note every trial. /  / 4.  After conducting 20 trials for every note, I will then plot all the data on a histogram based on the number of times she incorrectly identified the note before getting it right.  I will plot all the notes together on 1 histogram because they were all tested for in similar simulations. /      By looking at the histogram, I will be able to determine whether or not Clara has a "good ear for music."  If the majority of the data is located between small numbers (0-4), then it means that Clara had identified notes correctly more often than incorrectly; if the majority of the data is located between large (5-9), then it means that Clara had incorrectly identified notes more often.

I would keep track of the notes she gets right and wrong and I would look to see if she was consistent.
One can figure out the average first, then figure out the standard dev. to then determine who is a better fisher.
